As I use the pattern more and more, I am beginning to reconsider making
setUp() final for the very reason you mention.  I am running into
situations where concrete tests have more elaborate fixtures and it is
confusing to have the setup code in the create method.  I do think the
added clarity of having all setup code in setUp() is more valuable than
the "security" of having a final setUp method.

On Sat, 2002-02-09 at 11:04, Mike Clark wrote:
    On a separate note, I'm not sure I would preclude concrete test classes from
    overriding setUp() or tearDown().  Test fixtures are fundamental building
    blocks of JUnit tests.  If in fact a concrete test forgets to call
    super.setUp() in its overridden setUp(), then the test will fail anyway.  The
    advantages of adding to the fixture for concrete tests seems to outweigh the
    potential for abuse, in my opinion.
    
    Thanks for sharing this article!
    
    Regards,
    
    Mike
